org.vanilladb.core.storage.record

Class RecordFile

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.vanilladb.core.storage.record.RecordFile
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Record

    public class RecordFile
extends Object
implements Record
    Manages a file of records. There are methods for iterating through the records and accessing their contents. Note that the first block (block 0) of a record file is reserved for file header, and the actual data block is start from block 1.

    The insert() method must be called before setters.

    The beforeFirst() method must be called before next().

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructs an object to manage a file of records.

    • Constructor Detail

      • RecordFile

        public RecordFile(TableInfo ti,
                  Transaction tx,
                  boolean doLog)
        Constructs an object to manage a file of records. If the file does not exist, it is created. This method should be called by TableInfo only. To obtain an instance of this class, call TableInfo.open(Transaction, boolean) instead.
        Parameters:
        ti - the table metadata
        tx - the transaction
        doLog - true if the underlying record modification should perform logging

    • Method Detail

      • formatFileHeader

        public static void formatFileHeader(String fileName,
                                    Transaction tx)
        Format the header of specified file.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the file name
        tx - the transaction

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the record file.

      • remove

        public void remove()
        Remove the record file. TODO: handle the concurrency issues that might happen

      • beforeFirst

        public void beforeFirst()
        Positions the current record so that a call to method next will wind up at the first record.

      • next

        public boolean next()
        Moves to the next record. Returns false if there is no next record.
        Returns:
        false if there is no next record.

      • getVal

        public Constant getVal(String fldName)
        Returns the value of the specified field in the current record. Getter should be called after next() or moveToRecordId(RecordId).
        Specified by:
        getVal in interface Record
        Parameters:
        fldName - the name of the field
        Returns:
        the value at that field

      • setVal

        public void setVal(String fldName,
                   Constant val)
        Sets a value of the specified field in the current record. The type of the value must be equal to that of the specified field.
        Parameters:
        fldName - the name of the field
        val - the new value for the field

      • delete

        public void delete()
        Deletes the current record. The client must call next() to move to the next record. Calls to methods on a deleted record have unspecified behavior.

      • delete

        public void delete(RecordId rid)
        Deletes the specified record.
        Parameters:
        rid - the record to be deleted

      • insert

        public void insert()
        Inserts a new, blank record somewhere in the file beginning at the current record. If the new record does not fit into an existing block, then a new block is appended to the file.

      • insert

        public void insert(RecordId rid)
        Inserts a record to a specified physical address.
        Parameters:
        rid - the address a record will be inserted

      • moveToRecordId

        public void moveToRecordId(RecordId rid)
        Positions the current record as indicated by the specified record ID .
        Parameters:
        rid - a record ID

      • currentRecordId

        public RecordId currentRecordId()
        Returns the record ID of the current record.
        Returns:
        a record ID

      • fileSize

        public long fileSize()
        Returns the number of blocks in the specified file. This method first calls corresponding concurrency manager to guarantee the isolation property, before asking the file manager to return the file size.
        Returns:
        the number of blocks in the file
